Title: Parasite (Gisaengchung)
Review: A monumental achievement in film and the rare film that goes from "very good" to "historically great" in its final act.

Title: Parasite (Gisaengchung)
Review: The smartest mainstream film about class made in many years, Bong Joon-ho's Parasite lays bare the lie that hard work can bring anyone closer to their dreams.

Title: Parasite (Gisaengchung)
Review: Never let the audience off the hook, Hitchcock once said. Ho achieves this in spades and with more than one hook.

Title: Parasite (Gisaengchung)
Review: [A] funny, inventive, scary film.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: That their cast of non-professionals and unknowns represents immigrants, minorities and the disabled in such a unifying and uplifting work is all the more reason to embrace an independent film that just might restore your faith in humanity.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: As sharp as it is blunt, Give Me Liberty is a bravura piece of filmmaking. Although it's not always successful, it delivers a swift kick to an industry that has sidelined characters like these for far too long.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: Give Me Liberty's biggest victory is in avoiding depicting able-bodied driver Vic [Chris Galust] as the shining knight-in-armor savior, or sacrifice the other actors as props to inspire able-bodied audiences

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: It's the perspective of a thoroughly acculturated Russian immigrant who has nothing in life but his work and a crate of old vinyl.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: In his first foray into filmmaking, Mikhanovsky exhibits a strong sense for personal connection and certainly plenty of ambition in his style.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: [W]hen co-writer/director Mikhanovsky tries to imbue his ... story with more significance ... the filmmaker loses track of what makes his movie significant in the first place.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: "Give Me Liberty" is a must-see. Take some friends. Spread the word.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: It's a ride that opens the door to a diverse and important community. With wonderfully raw and absorbing performances, this small tale is a rare treat.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: A funny and charming indie with good performances by the non-professional cast.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: Mikhanosvky turns his camera on communities that are frequently marginalized in both film and in American society. Immigrants and people with disabilities are often ignored, rarely protagonists in films unless portrayed by a famous actor.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: Deep down, we're all in the same boat - or the same van.

Title: Give Me Liberty
Review: As the day deteriorates from erratic to near-disastrous, the collective ride shared between this inclusive cast of characters becomes not only a pleasantly-delivered dramatic and comedic experience, but a damn-near, compassionate one as well.
A series of disconnected scenes, rather than a narrative with a sense of momentum.
Though the title would have you believe you were watching a "futuristic" film involving robots, the truth is, it just feels like a cheesy soap opera or novella.
To simply dismiss it because of surface notions is to ignore the slippery slope of where we are going as a population ruled by new technological advancements everyday.

2050 is ostensibly a film about sex robots, hand-crafted by Dean Cain. But really, it's just a movie about terrible people rationalizing terrible behaviors in the most verbose, unnatural ways possible.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Banderas is the best part of the movie, with a tour-de-force performance...a master filmmaker forging a new path...

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: We are seeing the world - in all its sadness and beauty - through his eyes. Banderas brings it all to life.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: As slow and meandering as the film feels at times, DP José Luis Alcaine's eye is a constant that enlivens the screen when the narrative struggles to.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: In his assemblage of the film, Almodóvar imbues "Pain & Glory" with a wonderfully lyrical lilt. He weaves the film's many themes gracefully, with the measured contemplation of a musician putting together an album.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Like many of Almodovar's films, this one is emotional and personal. I think this film appeals to an older audience with its story about reconnecting with one's emotional center, after suffering despair brought on by age and medical problems.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Courtesy of Almodóvar's masterful direction and a career-finest performance from Banderas, we feel every moment with Salvador. The pain, the glory, and everything in-between.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: I love seeing Banderas directed by Almodóvar, especially in this role which is obviously a stand-in for the director himself. He uneasily occupies the screen, clearly trying to manage both his pain and his loved ones' response to it.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: This certainly feels like we know much more about the film's creator than from any of his (Almodóvar) other films.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Tonally, this is nothing new for Almodóvar, but there's something truly special about the groove he finds with Banderas.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: From his time in the wilderness, Almodóvar has emerged with a stunner. Heavily introspective, Pain and Glory is about aging and finding a reason to go on when your body fails and inspiration is lacking.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Its strands of fictionalized memoir work decently, but it's its more insightful look at religion and art throughout childhood that bring something to the table.

Title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
Review: Pedro Almodóvar's latest film is a masterpiece that balances the personal with the relatable.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: It's a better than decent thriller that you can catch on your telly.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: A well-written, well-acted and hard-hitting piece of material accompanied by an excellent musical score. And it features Timothy Spall and Hugh Bonneville in key roles as some of the villains indicated in the movie's title.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: Wastes its cast and intriguing potential with a cliche by the numbers gangster film that lacks energy or engaging suspense.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: Ably performed by a cast of some formidably notable talent joined by contemporary stars, there's nothing essentially wrong with Scalpello's latest... And yet, there's nothing to make this remarkably compelling or eventually memorable.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: Saddled with a convoluted plot.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: Violent, profane, but entertaining British gangster movie.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: The efforts of some talented actors are squandered in this by-the-numbers British crime thriller.

Title: The Corrupted
Review: Rather than a coherent conspiracy thriller, The Corrupted is several unrelated ideas jammed awkwardly together, and soaked in blood.

Title: Mine 9
Review: The simple storyline and real-life backdrop were fundamental to success, in a drama equal parts tragedy and compassion.

Title: Mine 9
Review: The results aren't golden, but this mine strikes a solid vein of silver with its subterranean drama.

Title: Mine 9
Review: Mine 9 is the most poignant and terrifying sort of drama: a film about good, hard working, sympathetic people in a life or death situation.

Title: Mine 9
Review: An indie film about a team of Appalachian coal miners trapped two miles down, trying to crawl their way up with an hour of oxygen, Mine 9 makes maximum use of the dark in all its frightening implications.

Title: Mine 9
Review: Mine 9 juggles too many characters, but it works in just about every other way. The acting is fantastic, the editing is dynamic, the directing subtlety builds tension, and the ending is really good.

Title: Mine 9
Review: A satisfyingly intense and efficiently filmed bit of counterprogramming for those suffering from superhero fatigue.

Title: Mine 9
Review: Mensore does his due diligence in showing us the claustrophobic, perilous conditions of the mine, even before disaster strikes...

Title: Mine 9
Review: ...here's a film about something real, not a horror picture about a group of shapely cavers who descend into the earth and get trapped with monsters chasing them. The monsters in the effective, streamlined thriller "Mine 9" are all around us.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: A fascinating if sometimes repetitive account of an emotionally abusive relationship between mother and son. The outdoor scenes that reference Lowry's paintings lighten the claustrophobia.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Martyn Hesford adapts his play for the screen with this very stagey and often uneasy two-hander, notable for fine work from Vanessa Redgrave and Timothy Spall...

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Timothy Spall's performance is a sterling study of understatement and pent-up frustration opposite a bed-bound Venessa Redgrave, who plays his domineering, ego-crushing horror of a mother.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: ...has a small canvas (sorry), and it suffers from a certain determined ordinariness, but it is affecting in other ways.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: On the screen, Mrs Lowry and Son, much like one of Lowry's own paintings, is a wee gem on a small canvas, full of loving details within its apparently simple and unadorned style.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: An essay on family, and life, by two of the greatest living actors.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Vanessa Redgrave and Timothy Spall give a master class in acting. The whole movie is a character study but what a study it is in the hands of these terrific thespians.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Biopic about artist's relationship with his bullying mother.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Mrs Lowry & Son ... is stuck in the mire of the worst aspects of their relationship and the monotonous narrative.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Mrs. Lowry And Son is by turns hilarious, brutal and tender, and like the best drama, it will leave you wondering what's going on behind the closed doors of all the other houses in Pendlebury and further afield.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: Mrs. Lowry and Son has an appealing old-school charm and two performances that make it worth seeing.

Title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
Review: A study of the painter LS Lowry that, with sly whimsy and darkness, finds a universality of the creative psyche via the toxic relationship with his mother, who tried (unsuccessfully) to crush him.

Title: The Two Popes

Title: The Two Popes
Review: ...we lose just a little too much momentum.

Title: The Two Popes
Review: Hopkins and Pryce lift Popes above its loose patchwork of monologue, flashback, and personal reckoning, and let the movie get down to its truest root: scaling the mystery that makes all men, even the most unknowable and sacrosanct, human.

Title: The Two Popes
Review: There's a simple pleasure in watching these two actors bring levity to godly men in their stiff robes.

Title: The Two Popes
Review: Well before its end, the film has settled into the groove of a corny buddy comedy so unreal that little trace remains of the serious issues at stake.

Title: The Two Popes
Review: This lively, intriguing and insistently humanistic flight of fancy... brims with wit, warmth and some tantalizing what-ifs.

Title: The Two Popes

Title: The Two Popes

Title: The Two Popes
Review: The magic of this mostly fictional film from Netflix is that it imagines an example of authentic listening and dialogue.

Title: The Two Popes

Title: The Two Popes

Title: Imprisoned

Title: Imprisoned

Title: Imprisoned

Title: Imprisoned
Review: Good intentions to highlight its setting's beauty and talent, aren't enough to save this unmemorable prison melodrama. [Full review in Spanish]

Title: Imprisoned

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi
Review: The stranded DeVine, for all his goofy charms as an actor, quickly exhausts our patience; he's in nearly every frame of this movie, and his screen partner is a phone, which means a hell of a lot of mugging for the camera.

Title: Jexi
Review: Lucas and Moore's film is filled with bugs, making it easy to unplug from its attempts to entertain and do literally anything else.

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi
Review: All I really know is I did not like Jexi, and it's hard for me to imagine many other people will.

Title: Jexi
Review: Adam Devine is more enjoyable in small doses - like supporting roles and not leading the charge. Michael Pena, we feel your pain. Come back, all is forgiven - this, Dora, everything!

Title: Jexi

Title: Jexi
Review: If you want to make a movie with some regressive, oft-repeated views on technology, at least commit to the bit. Otherwise, don't bother.

Title: Jexi

Title: Dark Encounter (Transience)

Title: Extracurricular
Review: It's fast paced, witty and sometimes sexy, a seductive package with a deceptively smart core and one of the best offerings for young audiences.

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata
Review: An underwhelming gothic horror film that's too low on palpable scares and suspense.

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata

Title: The Sonata

Title: Britt-Marie Was Here
Review: This is a small, sweet work that finds notes of grace that elevate it into something bordering on inspirational.

Title: Countdown

Title: Countdown
Review: Forget cheating death. In Countdown, it's the audience that really gets cheated.

Title: Countdown

Title: Countdown

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: It's a most loving poke at a genre left behind in the age of irony, when people didn't care how silly they looked as long as they got a chance to entertain.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: John Mulaney and the Sack Lunch Bunch is a definite recommend for a pretty wide audience. Perhaps not for those still watching children's programming but teens to adults will surely be entertained.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: The special combines everything that Mulaney is good at - dry jokes and asides, writing... catchy, entertaining musical numbers, and his performative earnestness that pairs shockingly well with a cast of absurdly talented children.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: It's not tongue-in-cheek; it means everything it puts out there, but it makes sure the audience knows how absurd it is because children are absurd-genuinely, sincerely, seriously absurd. They're weird and deep and dark, and this is the show they deserve.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: This colorful show takes a new approach to sketch comedy that falls flat in the areas of delivery, humor and cohesion.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: Mulaney, his cast, and his talented celebrity guests do well by the content they have, but this special is the best fit for older tweens and teens along with adult viewers.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: John Mulaney & the Sack Lunch Bunch excels at amplifying those weird moments of pre-adolescence, when you're trying to assert yourself more but aren't always taken seriously because you're "just a kid."

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
Review: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch is a perfect special debuting at the perfect time.

Title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch

Review: In addition to his Saturday Night Live hosting gigs, John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch serves as an ample reminder that Gyllenhaal is an effervescent and captivating comedic actor.

Review: Mulaney's in total control, and yet completely out of his element.

Title: Ghost Stories

Title: Ghost Stories

Title: Ghost Stories

Review: It should be noted that none of the four filmmakers - Anurag Kashyap, Zoya Akhtar, Dibakar Banerjee and Karan Johar - has made a horror movie before. God knows Johar has scared audiences, but this time, he's expected to.

Title: Speed of Life

Review: Director Maia Wechsler and her editor Mary Manhardt stayed on point with a difficult editing job to make this film hang together. It is almost too repititious...If you're not into dance particularly modern dance, this might not be for you.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: I found the film fascinating.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: Perhaps film can never really capture the essence of dance, but Wechsler does the next best thing and captures what it means to those involved in its creation.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: Though not a perfect film, I'm glad it is in the world. It's a quality record covering new ground in the dance documentary genre.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: If the Dancer Dances is obviously a must-see for any dancer, but even more than that, it's a good viewing experience for artists of any discipline.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: A rare privilege - to have this level of access to the creation of new work which is attempting to honor the legacy of such a legendary choreographer. An important document of an artistic process.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: While the film doesn't always give us access to its present-day subjects, it still offers valuable insight into issues of artistic preservation.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: Despite all of its strengths, If the Dancer Dances may simply be too esoteric for viewers who aren't already interested in dance.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: Revealing dissection of the demanding art of dancer/choreographer Merce Cunningham via a New York company's re-staging of one of his most famous pieces.

Title: If the Dancer Dances
Review: It's less of an insightful backstage documentary than a gushing, sycophantic love letter to the late Merce Cunningham.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: My problem with this movie... is that it wants us to empathize with Thomas Jane's character. But the thing is, his character's just a crooked cop.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: A police thriller with few police and fewer thrills, Crown Vic nevertheless offers a few rewards for the patient viewer, though these come wrapped in a derivative package.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: Crown Vic has strong performances and some topical observations of modern day police work, but it never goes anywhere interesting enough with them.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: A good film that unfortunately doesn't stand out from the crop. The performances by Thomas Jane and Luke Kleintank are solid and there are a few moments of real inspiration.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: The four-wheeled title character is more intriguing than its human counterparts in this gimmicky thriller.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: Crown Vic offers no ... sweeping sentiments, because it's too busy picking apart the mucky, gray morality of two men...

Title: Crown Vic
Review: "Crown Vic" doesn't sustain a level of suspense and grim analysis throughout the entire endeavor, keeping the picture uneven, but still connecting with undeniable moments of clarity.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: Not a bad picture. It's just too unexceptional to stand out.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: Overall, it's a very nicely made film, but its familiarity is likely to limit its audience potential and mean that [Joel] Souza's talent won't get the recognition it deserves.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: The result isn't perfect, but there's enough to peek inside this complex argument surrounding the police with nuanced emotion.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: Crown Vic proves to be a limited yet effective study of urban police work initiated by veterans who have gotten this far on street smarts and broken windows policing, rather than the new school of a community policing approach.

Title: Crown Vic
Review: [Thomas] Jane is the glue and mortar.

Title: Cubby
Review: ...this is not to say that Cubby is a bad film. It is quite a frothy mix of childish innocence and magical realism. It's just nothing of major consequence.

Title: Cubby
Review: Cubby is still vaguely enjoyable and endearingly weird, but it's still grades away from testing out of ordinariness.

Title: Cubby
Review: I personally enjoyed [Cubby] and the off-center oddity of NYC as filtered through an overly imaginative manchild with a penchant for Klonopin and psychedelic cupcakes.

Title: Cubby
Review: Despite being framed with a charming style, it unfortunately fails to draw out compelling connections amongst its characters.

Title: Cubby
Review: Very brave to portray yourself as being unable to connect with anyone your age. Most people put the coolest version of themself up onscreen if they are going to do so.

Title: Cubby
Review: The character of Mark Nabel wouldn't seem out of a place in a Will Ferrell slacker comedy, or one of Tim Robinson's more outlandish sketches - a familiar comic character, but one that feels thrillingly alien within a film aimed at queer audiences.

Title: Cubby
Review: By allowing the writing and direction to remain sympathetic to Mark, the film actually finds some important things to say about protective childhoods and the way we choose to treat people who are different from ourselves.

Title: Cubby
Review: [Mark] Blane tells the story of a man whose life is a mess without turning his film into a mess in the process, and that's trickier than it looks.

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: Antrum is pure folk horror eeriness, right down to the brilliantly off kilter score, and has the potential to be a major cult hit, given its ingenious hook.

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: Isn't amateurish enough to be charming or professional enough to pull off the con job.

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: It may not convince viewers that the film is cursed and they're going to die after watching it, but its commitment to the gimmick, its ethereal score, and its eerie imagery make for a creepy and effective throwback horror film.

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: Anyone who has a fondness for seventies grindhouse or even arthouse obscurities will find something to enjoy here, such is the attention to detail. Everything about the film-within-a-film appears authentic

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: the po-faced documentary sections which frame this film-within-a-film also serve to muddy its waters further, making us question precisely what we may be sacrificing of ourselves when we willingly suspend disbelief and yield to art's illusory sway.

Title: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made
Review: Tense and unnerving, unpredictable and mean spirited, Antrum... adds layers to the terrifying power of cinema.

Title: Drive
Review: Drive 2019 proves Tarun Mansukhani to be unfit for even a provisional licence to direct, presenting a watered-down, technically deficient bore that may as well have been renamed Drivel.

Title: Drive
Review: Trite action movie has mild language, product placement.

Title: Drive
Review: Whether Drive is so bad it's good, so unwatchable that it's watchable, a crack-a-box-of-wine-and-invite-your-friends-over-for-a-hate-watch is debatable.

Title: Drive
Review: Sushant Singh Rajput and Jacqueline Fernandez star in a cheap imitation of Fast & Furious, which has to be one of Netflix India's worst mistakes ever.

Title: Drive
Review: Gaping gaps in the plotline recede into the background in the face of ordinary car chases that routinely look plastic and an embarrassingly low-brow extended climax that feels like the work of an entry-level animation student.

Title: Drive
Review: Subtlety is not the film's forte. Neither is clarity, characterization, coherence or anything else that any reasonable person requires.

Title: Drive
Review: No scene or subplot in Drive has any reason to exist, but still, it continues to labour on.

Title: Klaus
Review: Klaus is the surprise of this awards season. [Full review in Spanish]

Title: Klaus
Review: Beyond the approachable storytelling, fun cast, and revisionist mythology, however, lies the stunning craftsmanship of the animation itself.

Title: Klaus
Review: Instead, it's a clever, not-too-sentimental Hatfields v McCoys take on the legend of Santa Claus.

Title: Klaus
Review: An engaging revisionist tale, destined to become another Christmas classic.

Title: Klaus
Review: While Klaus has a number of the same faults you'll find in a number of run-of-the-mill animated family movies . . . , more animated works could stand to take a cue from its visual creativity.

Title: Klaus
Review: A cut above the average seasonal tale due to its impressive cast and visual inventiveness, this film is full of unexpected references which will entertain older viewers but don't get in the way of the plot.

Title: Klaus
Review: The fluidity, the smoothness of the 3D animation...people, it looks good, incredible.

Title: Klaus
Review: This should be eligible for Best Animated Picture.

Title: Klaus
Review: Destined to be added to the yearly holiday viewing rotation, Klaus is worth writing to Santa about.

Title: Klaus
Review: The animation is beautiful, the story is beautiful, the music is beautiful.

Title: Klaus
Review: Sure you know where the story is going, but the journey is delightful nonetheless.

Title: Klaus
Review: Essentially a heartwarming tale of a millennial entrepreneur disrupting the status quo through social enterprise, Klaus is a pure pleasure to watch.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: It's difficult to connect with any of the characters and feel any sympathy for them.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: Earthquake Bird is definitely a cut above Netflix's usual fare. On a surface level the film doesn't have that weird plastic sheen Netflix releases always seem to be cheapened by.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: Earthquake Bird meanders through its plot points in a narrative that feels lost in translation.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: It's as if they built a portrait of a fascinating female killer and then chickened out, settling into the Lifetime "men are terrifying" model instead of exploring something more dynamic.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: An underwhelming, melodramatic story that culminates in a shaky ending dooms Earthquake Bird.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: Earthquake Bird is ultimately more of a puzzle than a thrill, leaving viewers to wonder what happened to Lily and what led to her disappearance.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: A mousy Alicia Vikander casts a convincing spell...and Westmoreland finds plenty of additional intrigue in this late 1980s Japanese setting...

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: Earthquake Bird is somewhat laborious in making its points, but it's a film whose unsettling qualities will grow on you with time.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: It's unfortunate that Earthquake Bird falls apart in the way that it does, as a film with this much of a unique premise and setting and populated with talented actors had such potential.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: There's a choppiness and impatience to the storytelling, with crucial scenes getting dispatched in a cursory fashion.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: Absorbing but slow tale has nudity, language, violence.

Title: Earthquake Bird
Review: If the frames are converted into data for a seismograph to read, be ready to see mainly flat lines.

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: The familial dynamic... is so strong that many of the story's obvious faults can be forgiven just by virtue of the fact we enjoy watching these people fight for their lives.

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: Even in its runtime, the movie disappoints by the sheer laziness of never pushing the screenplay to a possibly climactic finale. Instead, we get weak family non-drama and a series of uninteresting horror moments relying way more on blood than guts.

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: Red Letter Day has an idea, but neither the means to execute nor the vision to deliver a tooth-and-nail struggle against societal breakdowns.

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: Despite its initial slow start, Red Letter Day turns into a satisfying horror comedy that cleverly makes a sleepy little neighbourhood wake up and as the violence, horror and the black comedy laughs ensue...

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: In many ways Red Letter Day is a humour heavy, daylight spin on The Purge, one which works well, but could benefit from a longer run time.

Title: Red Letter Day
Review: Taking its cue from The Purge (2013) and Assassination Nation (2018), this grimly allegorises a country all too easily polarised against itself, street by bloody street. For once those letters have arrived, everyone goes postal.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: Despite all the missteps, Cole and Burt are onto something here. The film is sprinkled with some surprisingly deep psychological insight and neon-noir-ish colors...

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: With a sumptuous color palette, Philophobia will leave viewers viscerally intoxicated despite the purposeful mental scarring.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: This film could be the ultimate film to watch for those with a fear of commitment, you'll either understand where the main character is coming from, or will feel so uncomfortable that you'll be running for the door.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: ...Philophobia is a strange mix of comedy and horror that's, unfortunately, only intermittently effective.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: The dating scene in Los Angeles can be hellish, but Philophobia: or the Fear of Falling in Love takes kicks it up a notch. A stylish and intriguing debut, the film is a worthy watch as this holiday season takes off.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: Tyler Cole's debut feature is unlike any breakup movie before it.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: What's more amusing... is how you can almost predict its ending right from the start, but you are still kept engaged and curious to see how it is going to reach that climax. It manages to stay adequately entertaining and pleasurable to sit through.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: Philophobia may mean 'fear of love,' but this is clearly a labor of it.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: The aesthetic choices and percussive pervasiveness in the score help represent Damien, the man, the podcaster and philophobic. This project is clearly a labour of love and I'm looking forward to Tyler Cole's next production.

Title: Philophobia: Or the Fear of Falling in Love
Review: A sharp, intelligent and original rom-com.

Title: Radioflash
Review: A heroine as strong as Reese deserves a more consistently exciting plot.

Title: Radioflash
Review: In truth, this "Deliverance"-style clash between Reese, a savvy teenager, and a passel of backwoods archetypes is only marginally more thrilling than the average wine tasting.

Title: Radioflash
Review: The result is an offbeat conceptual mixture, albeit one that's somewhat frustrating and occasionally tedious, if beautifully photographed by Austin Schmidt.

Title: Radioflash
Review: You just want to be immersed in any aspect of the film. Instead, we're given a boatload of lackluster moments with superfluous dialogue and trace amounts of danger.

Title: Radioflash
Review: Nancy Drew meets the apocalypse in this mild-mannered coming of age road trip.

Title: Radioflash
Review: Inept post-EMP survival thriller is no more thrilling than it is plausible, and inexcusably casts its resourceful teen heroine as a victim constantly at the mercy of others and in need of rescuing.

Title: Radioflash
Review: Radioflash is a film at war with its own ideas, its central themes in conflict with one another and its plot spiralling out in complexity as film progresses.

Title: Radioflash
Review: The pacing feels sluggish in some places, and jumpy in others, which doesn't give Sharbino's Reese an honest chance to earn her action-hero conclusion.

Title: Radioflash
Review: Radioflash is less a cohesive story than it is a series of ideas cobbled together.

Title: Radioflash
Review: Wants to be a lot of things, but never really comes together, with McPherson overwhelmed by his subplots, struggling to find a story worth following from start to finish.

Title: Radioflash
Review: It's a lazy hero's quest adventure flick where the hero learns little and isn't given much chance to become a hero.

Title: Primal
Review: Despite its flaws, I warmed to Primal as it neared its close, and not just because it was nearly at a close. It's enjoyable nonsense that becomes weirdly compulsive viewing.

Title: Primal
Review: Nicolas Un-Caged - that's what you could call this man versus nature actioner. Nicolas Cage returns to his action roots with Primal, a high octane action film which takes subtlety and tosses it overboard.

Title: Primal
Review: Despite the "Cage vs. jaguar" hook that is being relied on to sell the movie, there isn't a whole lot of gnarly animal action.

Title: Primal
Review: Is Primal good? Not exactly. But it is a film in which Nicolas Cage goes man-hunting on a ship full of snakes and parrots and monkeys [...] and, in a way, that's good enough.

Title: Primal
Review: At its best, Primal calls to mind Adam Sandler's Netflix originals, where it's clear the actor is just going on vacation to different locals and hoping the creatives around him can put together a movie from the exploits.

Title: Primal
Review: How have I not been transported back to the 90s where Primal should be opening in wide-release alongside every other audacious action hybrid imaginable?

Title: Primal
Review: This modest action-adventure B movie offers a bit more pleasure than guilt. [Full review in Spanish]

Title: Primal
Review: When Primal focuses on Nicolas Cage and his uncaged beasts it manages to deliver enough silly fun to stand apart from his other releases this year.

Title: Primal
Review: The latest in Nicolas Cage's seemingly endless stream of B-movie potboilers [is] ludicrously implausible-as well as unpleasantly claustrophobic.

Title: Primal
Review: Primal simply refuses to dive into the wackiness of the premise, and a generally straight-faced presentation is not what most people want from a movie that features Nicolas Cage, Famke Janssen, a homicidal maniac, and a bunch of wild animals on a boat.

Title: Primal
Review: Primal is like Life of Pi meets The Silence of the Lambs, only way less fun than that sounds.

Title: Primal
Review: The only thrills are of the guilty-pleasure variety, although there's little camp value in the mechanical script or the technical incompetence.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: A lovely small-scale story about two men reconnecting with themselves and their families.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: "Cold Brook" is proof that solid character-driven films can be made on a small budget, and with maximum talent.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: The deliberately paced film is slight but heartfelt, with endearing performances.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: A very well done, simply made film.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: Are You Ready To Be Different: Part ghost tale, part Bartleby while at the same time a captivating slavery reparations fable, the film flirts with the supernatural even with its heart planted firmly in sobering class and race issues historically and now.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: Cold Brook is an adult fairy tale that embraces its broad interpretations to remind its leading men about what truly matters most.

Title: Cold Brook
Review: ... Cold Brook succeeds in part by its fantastic cast, but mostly by its focus on simplicity. There're no grand fights or superfluous moments, just a tale of love that transcends time and mortal existence.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Gender stereotypes, charming family love in Christmas tale.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: A nostalgic, Christmastime movie that warms the audience the more it lets its believable cast of characters bounce off one another.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Tinnell's film Feast of the Seven Fishes is a warm-hearted, consciously low-stakes romantic comedy that, for me, at least, succeeds where so many "feel-good" holiday movies have fallen short: it actually made me feel good.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: It might be the perfect film for the viewer who wants to see an undemanding traditional family film during the holiday season.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Unlike the titular meal, there's not much substance to the nostalgic screenplay, even if the ensemble cast brings a heartfelt charm to the predictable material.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: The whole thing becomes an enjoyable, if slight, slice of life that will ring true to anyone with an annual holiday tradition as chaotic as it is essential.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: One of those low-budget films that is made with such sincerity and genial good nature that one feels a little bad for pointing out that, despite all of its obvious good intentions, it just isn't that interesting.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: [Despite the number of] subplots, Christmas Eve slows things down to make the camaraderie of preparing [dinner] an excuse to go into a trance of unadulterated joy.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Moments of heartfelt family traditions come first, while the established plot comes second, but the film is an enjoyable experience with memorable moments and strong performances.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Warm and revitalising, Feast Of The Seven Fishes is the perfect Christmas treat.

Title: Feast of the Seven Fishes
Review: Call it what it is, Christmas comedy comfort food. And bring your appetite.

Title: The Shed
Review: An interesting morality tale, by way of vampires, about the nature of power between the bullies and the bullied.

Title: The Shed
Review: The social subtext doesn't carry much weight alongside the supernatural nonsense, and it's difficult to find sympathy for these characters who consistently lack common sense.

Title: The Shed
Review: In the end, The Shed is not quite good enough to be worth seeing, but it is just good enough to make one curious about what Sabatella might have to offer the next time around.

Title: The Shed
Review: It's more concerned with how the traumatized people act when facing danger rather than just telling about the vampire's urge to kill.

Title: The Shed
Review: If there's one thing The Shed gets right, it's reassuring viewers that vampires can be savage, malicious creatures of nightly fury.

Title: The Shed
Review: This indie shocker starts strong but doesn't know how to leverage its slick premise.

Title: The Shed
Review: Without turning into a cheesy after school special, Sabatella spins a classic '80s yarn into brilliant social commentary.

Title: The Shed
Review: RIP sparkly moody vampires, as The Shed takes them back to the monstrous beings they have always meant to be.

Title: The Shed
Review: It operates on familiar tropes ... and then it twists it in very dark directions. It's just unfortunate it ultimately devolves into a stereotypical battle with an ancient evil.

Title: The Shed
Review: The Shed offers a version of the vampire mythos that is deeply rooted in fears and concerns of today and has a valuable lesson: don't be a bully, because you never know what is hiding in the bullied kid's shed.

Title: The Shed
Review: Although the horror tropes here are familiar ones, The Shed is well put together and, unlike many films of its ilk, actually has something to say. There's a solidity at its core that will endear it to fans and see it linger in the memory.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: The lo-fi production casts an ambitious net and smartly makes the most of its cloistered locations... framing it all in tight and embossing the emotional impact.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: Despite obviously limited resources, Lyman-Clarke delivers a thoroughly engaging thriller that keeps you hooked from beginning to end.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: While "Night Sweats ... keeps you involved and arouses your curiosity about the cause of the disease, the movie's very limited budget handcuffs the film, as it uses few sets and locales around New York City.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: Regardless of what you think of the gangling plot, the vomit effects are pretty darned marvelous.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: Despite these issues, a discernible micro-budget, and a poorly-realized degenerative brain ailment, the film could have worked were it not for the big reveal...

Title: Night Sweats
Review: Run of the mill movie about deadly disease, but there is a nice twist to it all.

Title: Night Sweats
Review: An intriguing but cut-rate thriller that (unfortunately) looks it.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: It's a haunting drama that skilfully avoids cliches.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: Intriguing but limited Dutch character study that turns in the second half into an action-thriller.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: Moody and bristling, the dramatic character study sobers up just in time for some bruising action.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: Bloody Marie falls short on almost every front. Marie herself is an unlikeable mess of a character who only amounts to be the centrepiece of a film that was never fully realised as the thrill-ride it was supposed to be.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: A fraught Dutch thriller about an alcoholic's biggest, perhaps deadliest mistake.

Title: Bloody Marie
Review: ...a shot of adrenaline in a landscape filled with cinematic clones.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: A likable cast does justice to this cheesy teenage X-mas rom-com tale.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: You're likely to have an endearing cinematic experience because Let It Snow is all about the feels. And that, is something that hits the mark for everyone, regardless of how old you are.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: Compared to the usual Hallmark-dominated landscape of straight-up straight, white, and boring holiday movies, this does feel like a breath of fresh air.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: The characters here are less performatively quirky and as a result more likeable than your usual [John] Green teens.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: Let It Snow has charm aplenty, but with so many plates spinning its hard to elicit a huge emotional investment, as with Netflix's own To All the Boys I've Loved Before. But it's okay to not fall for all of these love stories.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: Let It Snow is a very silly movie with a lot of heart, nailing the holiday formula with strong production values and an impressive young cast.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: With moments of sweetness, outweighing the blandness of the overall feeling of the film, the little tiny moments of comedy are welcome and actually start to make you enjoy the film despite the very obvious messages it is sending...

Title: Let It Snow
Review: For what it's worth, thanks to a proficient director in Luke Snellin and a talented young cast, Let It Snow ends up being A-OK.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: Gets a pass for being entertaining and wholesome while embracing the rich modern diversity of this generation.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: I love Shipka and it has Prince Ben (Mitchell Hope) from Descendants in it, which you will find exciting if you are, as I mentioned, a teen or tween.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: As it works its way through a litany of clichés, Let It Snow occasionally happens across a sincere moment, but, in a way, that just makes the film more frustrating.

Title: Let It Snow
Review: Teen ensemble romcom is fun; language, drinking.

Title: Line of Duty
Review: A forgettable but watchable high-energy police thriller.

Title: Line of Duty
Review: The tone veers haphazardly from tense, high-stakes cat-and-mouse chase to ill-judged satire...

Title: Line of Duty
Review: combines improbable buddy comedy with vicious shoot-outs, bruising punch-ups and overblown pathos, while letting an ageing cowboy loose in the internet age. The results are a riotous real-time ride - albeit just as immediately forgettable.

Review: The messages are bad and the movie is bad. It's plain and clear why the studio dumped this on Netflix internationally.

Title: Being Frank

Title: Being Frank
Review: It's hard to say who's more at fault: writer, director, actors, pool boy.

Title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes

Review: There are smart, mature, women-centric originals on streaming services. But, there are been duds too. For every shining OITNB, Handmaid's Tale, and Marvelous Mrs. Maisel, there's the other end of the spectrum. In this case, it's called Otherhood.

Title: Otherhood

Title: Otherhood

Title: Otherhood

Title: Otherhood
Review: Short on laughter, the fun seems fake. Pouts and shouting are hard to take. Three lovely stars try acting their best. Yet humor fails the comedy test.

Title: Otherhood
Review: Escapism and heartache with tedious, self-involved personalities, while attention to genuine humor is missing from the endeavor.

Title: Otherhood
Review: Littered with bad jokes, corny one-liners and predictable writing, Otherhood embraces its cliches in order to deliver on the heart.

Title: Otherhood
Review: Otherhood doesn't explore any of this with any degree of social or political insight. Instead, it deploys all that inequity, emptiness, and rejection for cheap laughs; these middle-aged moms' debasement is the gag.

Title: Otherhood

Title: The White Crow

Title: The White Crow

Title: The White Crow

Title: The White Crow

Title: The White Crow

Title: The White Crow
Review: The White Crow offers up all these elements of Nureyev - his past, his heat, his vulnerabilities - but all those parts are dancing around each other incongruously rather than as a well-choreographed ensemble piece.

Title: The White Crow
Review: Lacks that passion, spark and danger which made Nureyev such a master.

Title: The White Crow
Review: It was probably a much better idea to get a real Russian ballet dancer to play the role rather than an English-speaking actor with a phoney Russian accent and a dance double.

Title: The White Crow
Review: ...a taut dramatic thriller that is as much about overcoming adversity and the drive of an artist to be free, as it is about Nureyev, the Cold War or ballet.

Title: The White Crow
Review: The solid final 20 minutes of the film demonstrate how strong a director Fiennes can be, but it's a slow, obviously deliberate build up that might test the patience of those who don't have a standing interest in the dancer or of this period in history.

Title: The White Crow
Review: The Nureyev story is a very good one, and Fiennes and Hare tell it well.

Title: The White Crow
Review: In his biographical drama, director Ralph Fiennes takes a plodding yet scattershot approach to dancer Rudolph Nureyev.

Title: Trial by Fire
Review: The actress (Dern) brings her trademark intelligence and tenacity to the character, and the film also features strong supporting performances.

Review: Excellent performances by Laura Dern and Jack O'Connell lend credence to this message movie.

Title: Trial by Fire

Title: Trial by Fire

Title: Trial by Fire
Review: You come out of this film deeply moved and also overwhelmed by a group of memorable performances.

Review: Takes a fascinating, suspenseful true story and waters it down into a generic, maudlin, anti-death-penalty message.

Title: Trial by Fire

Title: Trial by Fire

Title: Charlie Says

Title: Charlie Says

Title: Charlie Says

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Charlie Says is a film about female solidarity in even the harshest circumstances, rather than yet another take on the Charles Manson story.

Title: Charlie Says

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Looking at the women looking at Charles Manson, "Charlie Says" is a frustrating watch that never really reveals why they did what they did. Murray and Wever are terrific though, and Harron nails that end-of-decade twisting of idealism and optimism.

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Harron and Turner are making a wider point about the nature of demagoguery and the willingness of people to be led. It's easy to look back with fifty years of hindsight and realise little has changed.

Title: Charlie Says
Review: The cultural weight of the Manson Family Murders...will always be a tough, almost unexplainable mindset to recreate and explain from both the women and Manson himself, but Harron is adept at turning the tables to present a fresh and feminist perspective.

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Although uncomfortably lurid in places, the film stops short of the full-on exploitative treatment it could have warranted.

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Harron's film is at its most thoughtful, and its most useful, in moments where it presents itself as an exploration of young women in thrall to a charismatic, deeply egotistical leader who thrives on their willing submission.

Title: Charlie Says
Review: Charlie Says, for all its contemplative trappings, is no less exploitative than many other Manson films.

Title: Nekrotronic

Title: UglyDolls

Title: UglyDolls
Review: A 90-minute commercial for toys disguised as an entertainment.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: Not so much a movie as a contemplative space wherein the viewer ... explores the shifting dynamic between the eponymous plush toys and the hegemony of play.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: Thankfully, the voice cast is packed with popstars who are great at pouring sparky attitude into their performances.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: Certain scenes may scare more sensitive children but, on the whole, UglyDolls is cutely done, and it earns extra plaudits for being an animation for younger kids that attempts to address age-relevant issues of individuality.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: While the design is visually striking there's nothing beyond the paper-thin, by-the-numbers nature of UglyDolls.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: This paean to body positivity and living your own truth is more than welcome, but you just wish UglyDolls' message could be more charmingly argued, adroitly assembled and just plain funny.

Title: UglyDolls
Review: UglyDolls' worst feature is that it's rather bland. For a movie about embracing one's differences, it does seem to be pretty much identical to the many other 'summer holiday kids movies' out there.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Unlike Knocked Up, which also featured Rogen as a schlub paired off with a woman seemingly well out of his league, this works hard to show why both characters would be into each other despite their surface differences.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Long Shot may not be the return of the romcom, but it's certainly a real return to form.

Title: Long Shot
Review: ...despite the clunky, unimaginative script and the by-the-numbers direction, Long Shot is saved by the exact gimmick that probably green-lit it in the first place: Theron and Rogen.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Broad appeal with Long Shot as it plays to the Seth Rogen fan base, the rom com watchers, and anyone that enjoys political comedies. It's smarter and funnier than you'll want to give it credit for.

Title: Long Shot
Review: The way Long Shot differentiates itself from the sexist sitcom cliche is by exploring the difficulty men have in ceding power to women, even if-perhaps especially if-the women are clearly more skilled and intelligent.

Title: Long Shot
Review: It's not a new Valentine's Day classic perhaps, but there are enough warm, fuzzy feelings, along with many laughs, to qualify for date night.

Title: Long Shot
Review: It has everything you want in a romantic comedy and more.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Long Shot somehow makes it all work

Title: Long Shot
Review: Even when the story is treading well-worn territory, Rogen and Theron are so authentic and lively together that you don't care you know exactly where it's going, you're just happy to be along for the ride.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Though it lacks a certain edge, Long Shot is a tight, funny, and warm comedy with a ton of heart and two fantastic performances at its center.

Title: Long Shot
Review: While flirting with some disturbing political truths, the film sometimes mistakes fatuity for freshness. If anything, it works as a showcase for the actors.

Title: Long Shot
Review: Long Shot is actually romantic and genuinely a comedy.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: This is a film rooted in a ludicrous concept that doesn't just work, but excels because of the amount of heart that has gone into making it. It's earnest, endearing, and well worth a Pika.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: It's just nice, it's a nice pleasant thing. I think if you yourself have Pokemon nostalgia you'll probably get some enjoyment out of this, just don't expect to be surprised by the plot.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Detective Pikachu is a fun family movie that can be enjoyed by many. It's a love letter to the world of Pokémon and easily the best video game movie made.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Detective Pikachu wears its influences on its sleeve, and has the sensibilities of a Stephen Spielberg-produced picture.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Rob Letterman's film is a standard kids' movie blend of knockabout comedy and CGI fantasy action, but Detective Pikachu himself is a proper star.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Solid family fun.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Smart, imaginative and sweet, Detective Pikachu offers something for everyone.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Even though Pokemon implores you to "catch 'em all," this is one you're going to want to release back into the wild.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: I found this weirdly diverting... It's a counterintuitive fit for this character, and I kind of liked that about it.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: A seriously weird and heartfelt film jam-packed with action and chock full of Pokemon - what more could you ask for?

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: While by no means perfect, 'Pokemon Detective Pikachu' can nevertheless comfortably lay claim to being the best videogame adaptation ever made.

Title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
Review: Pokémon: Detective Pikachu is a rather silly idea in conception, but in execution, it's a pretty compelling tale that features plenty of twists and turns, and well-rendered CGI.

Title: Fast Color
Review: A very rich, lively, humane mess.

Title: Fast Color
Review: [Gugu Mbatha-Raw] delivers a laudable, restrained, and complex performance. [Full review in Spanish]

Title: Fast Color
Review: A terrific movie that juggles several different genres with enormous skill and economy.

Title: Fast Color
Review: A subdued take on the superhero film...

Title: Fast Color
Review: It's a strange and enticing mix: a superhero origin story and sci-fi paranormal effects mix with apocalyptic allegory.

Title: Fast Color
Review: Fast Color, a low-budget, sci-fi indie drama (...) operates within the superhero sub-genre, but without the plastic, toy-selling bombast these films have become known for.

Title: Fast Color
Review: ... don't confuse Fast Color for a standard superhero tale. This isn't a story in which heroes level cities in their quest to defeat evil, but is one of unconditional love, creation, and sacrifice.

Title: Fast Color

Title: Fast Color
Review: Through visions of family and generational trauma, Fast Color stands tall as a specialty listing, something I would call a "Pre-Power" story. When that power comes alive, the results reach fantastical heights.

Title: Fast Color

Title: Fast Color
Review: The more you find out, the more [Julia] Hart's film settles into a kind of ponderous groove that eventually works its way into a solid story arc but struggles to register on the Richter scale.

Title: Fast Color
Review: One of those small, mighty movies that can easily slip under the radar in a busy season of blockbusters.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: The Coming Race doesn't have the love and affection of its predecessor, nor does it have a sense of discipline or focus, and unfortunately falls flat.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: As much as this premise could make for a good time, it's largely a bore and a mess.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: Call it mindless schlock if that makes you feel better about liking it, but campy movies are supposed to be ridiculous and entertaining. Iron Sky: The Coming Race is light years from the latter.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: Noisy and unfunny, still pawing at the same obvious political targets while expanding its capacity for mayhem, hoping to wow viewers instead of tickle them with relentless absurdity.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: The Coming Race might not sell the need for this absurd series to continue, it at least provides a reason to go back and watch the original, and help its creators get the money they need to try to recapture their uniquely bizarre form of movie magic.

Title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
Review: ... there's something so refreshing, so pure, about the Iron Sky series in what it attempts, that audiences can't help but get swept up in its wake.

Title: Little Woods
Review: DaCosta, Thompson, and James have created something tense and timely and empathetic in Little Woods, further expanding the Western genre and adding another slice of American life to it.

Title: Little Woods
Review: [Tessa] Thompson's forceful, charismatic performance brings life to what could have been a relentlessly grim film, but it also unbalances the drama somewhat.

Title: Little Woods
Review: This is a film of high tension about two sisters living on the edge of ruin in the farthest northern reaches of North Dakota. One slip up and they could end up homeless, or in jail. The only things they have to rely on are their wits and each other.

Title: Little Woods
Review: A predictable narrative given rich contours...

Title: Little Woods
Review: The film may not look impressive, but I am impressed by how [writer-director Nia] DaCosta introduces complications into this already complicated story without straining for effect.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Though it may be on the nose at times, Little Woods is a tense and emotional look at the political issues we're arguing about today that are affecting people's lives.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Little Woods acts as a slow-burning drama that too often extinguishes the tension just as things are heating up.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Little Woods is a film that more people need to see, as it is not only a compelling survival drama, but it is a enlightening examination at a slice of Americana, an involving crime western and a touching look at a strong sisterly bond.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Little Woods can be bleak, but it's a good choice if you're looking for some substance among the Hollywood blockbusters out this season.

Title: Little Woods
Review: The directorial debut by Nia DaCosta is a stunning, deep and thoughtful portrait of two marginalised women in America forgotten by city folk and the political class.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Writer-director Nia DaCosta's debut feature is a bravura and, at times, bleak look at women living on the poverty line in small-town America.

Title: Little Woods
Review: Visually striking. Comparisons to Debra Granik's Winter's Bone and Leave No Trace are fitting...

Title: Ash Is Purest White

Title: Ash Is Purest White

Title: Ash Is Purest White
Review: For anyone with a long investment in Jia Zhengke's artistry, it's not hard to find what he achieves here to be another masterwork.

Title: Ash Is Purest White

Title: Ash Is Purest White

Title: Ash Is Purest White

Title: Ash Is Purest White
Review: Cinephiles craving something more substantial than Hollywood's fast and furious follies would do well to spare a couple of hours for Ash Is The Purest White this weekend.

Title: Ash Is Purest White
Review: An intimate story of romance, betrayal and loss gets framed against the sweeping, epic backdrop of radical, socio-economic changes in China.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: It would have been fresh to set this film in Mexico, centred on a Mexican family and have it steeped in an entirely different landscape and culture. Instead, it's the same story seen many times before - an innocent American family targeted by ghouls.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: The appearance by Father Perez marks this as another entry in The Conjuring Universe, but I daresay that a character from a different Warner property -- say, Clint Eastwood's drug smuggler from The Mule -- would have made for a more interesting crossover.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: The Curse of La Llorona whitewashes iconic Mexican folklore and replaces it with tense scares but nothing of substance.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: The movie delivers on the jump scares, and gets extra points for exploring Mexican folklore. Yet, The Curse of La Llorona suffers from generic plot and easily forgettable characters.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: Director Michael Chaves ramps up the Spielbergian flair in the final act, with a spookhouse run of more playful malevolence than perfunctory motion. But after two acts of overly telegraphed terror, you just don't fear the weeper.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: Velasquez doesn't have many lines...but she uses the ones she has to make as much of an impact as possible.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona

Review: The lack of creativity and innovation kills the film stone dead. It is clear that the filmmakers need to reinvent the formula and fast, before it dries out like an exhumed corpse.

Title: The Curse of La Llorona

Title: The Curse of La Llorona
Review: Pretty much everything about the project is too generic to really make an impression.

Title: Teen Spirit

Title: The Wedding Guest

Title: The Wedding Guest

Title: The Wedding Guest

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
Review: The film manages to honor the original series' setting and themes while delivering a completely different type of martial arts film that is wholly entertaining all by itself.

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
Review: Master Z stretches the limits of how far out one can franchise a biographical film before it devolves into fan fiction.

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
Review: Not bad. What's next in the endless stream of Ip Man movies? Probably in the next Matrix, Ip Man teaches Keanu Reeves's Neo, who will then come out of his trance state and proclaim, "I know better kung fu."

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
Review: My expectations might not have been exceeded in any way, but they were solidly met. I'd happily revisit another one of these tangential adventures in the future.

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy

Title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
Review: Director Woo-Ping Yuen and producers Donnie Yen and Dave Bautista, who also appears in the film, along with legendary Michelle Yeoh, give this martial arts a lot of class.

Title: Blood Paradise

Title: Blood Paradise

Title: Batman: Hush

Title: Batman: Hush

Title: Batman: Hush
